Award.AwardTitle: DRRC: Dynamics between Local and Foreign Actors: Influences on Capabilities in Post-Earthquake Rural Haiti and Hurricane Impacted Rural Gulf Coast

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research is a comparative study of disaster-affected rural communities (the U.S. Gulf Coast and Haiti) that explores the interactions between international actors and rural communities during recovery efforts and their influences on the capabilities of disaster-affected individuals. The study inquires into the social production of disaster recovery, theorized to be a function of social discourses, social policies, the norms of the humanitarian and development industries, and local cultures. The research involves a content analysis of public policies, media discourses, and organizational documents. The research team is interviewing local and external organizational actors connected to each of the target communities (three in Haiti and three on the Gulf Coast) with a specific focus on community actor participation in disaster recovery projects. As well, a random community survey in each of the six communities gauges individual disaster recovery, participation, social capital, and capabilities-based recovery. By employing a capabilities approach (a human development framework utilized in global poverty studies and more modestly in disaster recovery), this research advances capabilities scholarship, further clarifying what capabilities are most important to facilitate sustainable disaster recovery in rural settings.

The research team prepares a case study for each community, in addition to comparing communities on intervention practices, especially participation, and recovery capabilities sets. The findings contribute to the production of a guide and training for international actors working in disaster recovery settings, focusing on practical applications of local-external partnership building, providing professionals with an opportunity to advance skills in sustainable disaster recovery practices. Important benefits can accrue to rural communities impacted by disasters as a result of this research, providing them with greater opportunities to participate in their own recovery efforts and gain benefits from technical assistance and other direct supports from international partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research compared citizen participation in disaster recovery activities in rural communities from two disasters - Hurricane Katrina, which hit the Gulf Coast of the U.S. in 2005, and the earthquake in Haiti, which erupted in 2010. Survey research revealed that citizen participation in community disaster recovery projects was significantly higher in rural communities on the Gulf Coast than in Haiti. On the Gulf Coast, of the 259 people surveyed, 54% reported participating in a disaster recovery project. In Haiti, of the 278 people surveyed, 21% had participated. The researchers surmise these discrepancies to be a function of two phenomena – 1) higher baseline capacities on the Gulf Coast to engage in community work; and 2) the greater ability of disaster recovery projects to engage local people. In Haiti, participation is predicted by home ownership, having personal property destroyed in the disaster, and belief in the importance of citizens in disaster recovery. On the Gulf Coast, participation is predicted by higher age, having one’s physical and mental health impacted by the disaster, and higher levels of general civic engagement (e.g. voting).

Other data was also analyzed including discourse of the New York Times, state policy documents, and documents of international non-governmental organizations (INGOs).  The analysis revealed that much of the discourse failed to fully acknowledge the needs of rural communities, instead focusing most of their attention and efforts on urban Port-au-Prince and New Orleans. On the Gulf Coast, the government is viewed as a failure, while in Haiti the government is viewed as absent. On both Haiti and the Gulf Coast, there is a strong fixation on economic recovery and development, including the opportunity to “build back better.” On the Gulf Coast, there is more attention given to a mental health crisis in terms of increase in depression, PTSD, and suicide rates in the context of the near collapse of the mental health system. In Haiti, there is some attention given to the increase of mental health issues, but in the context of an almost non-existent mental health system before the disaster. As well, Haitians are often described as “impressively resilient.” In both locations, there is significant discussion about the ways that individuals, groups, and communities worked to take matters into their own hands through mutual aid, citizen engagement in recovery planning, protest, and entrepreneurialism.

Overall, researcher recommendations for policymakers and disaster responders in both locations include an emphasis on holistic recovery, listening and partnering with rural communities, building on the collectivist practices of rural communities, and developing capacities for transformative solutions to risk reduction. Finally, the researchers recommend that outside actors study the context they are working in, acknowledge their own intentions for their work, and to develop cultural competence. This is especially important in places like Haiti where there is a strong reliance on international actors to lead recovery processes.
